pr_title: Selectively enforce lookup class package check

timeline.bodyText: This looks wrong - code that's explicitly asking for the check should be updated for 15 rather than discarding the value here.
timeline.author: DanHeidinga

replies.bodyText:
The approach of this PR is to always skip the package check other than those three APIs in question for JDK15. Those three have been modified to invoke the Lookup constructor with true flag for JDK15 (to match RI behaviours). The expectation is that all other JDK15 API don't perform such check.
Does this make sense?
replies.author: JasonFengJ9

timeline.author: DanHeidinga

timeline.message:
Selectively enforce lookup class package check

Only following APIs are subject to lookup class package check:

MethodHandles.Lookup	.in​(Class<?> lookupClass)
MethodHandles.Lookup.dropLookupMode​(int modeToDrop)
MethodHandles.Lookup	.privateLookupIn​(Class<?> targetClass,
MethodHandles.Lookup caller)


Signed-off-by: Jason Feng <fengj@ca.ibm.com>

Only following APIs are subject to lookup class package check:

MethodHandles.Lookup caller)

timeline.author: DanHeidinga

replies.author: JasonFengJ9

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't this be false?  If the user already has a Lookup in the java.lang.invoke package, why would we restrict dropping access?
timeline.author: DanHeidinga

replies.bodyText:
new Lookup(accessClass, newPrevAccessClass, newAccessMode)  invokes this(lookupClass, prevLookupClass, lookupMode, true), so the flag was true in current code base, i.e., always check the package.
This check matches RI behaviours which was introduced for defense-in-depth fix [1], and still presents in JDK15.
[1] http://mail.openjdk.java.net/pipermail/jigsaw-dev/2017-April/012268.html
replies.author: JasonFengJ9

replies.bodyText: It's an odd restriction to leave at this point but as it matches the RI, we'll do the same for 15.
replies.author: DanHeidinga
